 KYRGYZ REPUBLIC PRIVATE ENTERPRISE SUPPORT PROJECT I. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Kyrgyz Republic (KR), with an estimated per capita income of US$830 in 1993, is among the smallest and poorest of the former Soviet Republics with modest natural resources but a literate population of 4.4 million. The present government, headed by President Askar Akaev who led the pro-reform and pro- democracy movement, is committed to macroeconomic stabilization and the establishment of a market economy. To achieve these goals, the Kyrgyz Republic Government (KRG) looks primarily to the international finance institutions for advice and financial support. Kyrgyzstan was one of the four Former Soviet Union (FSU) recipients of World Bank assistance under the 1992 Technical Co-operation Program (TCP). Despite a large terms of trade deterioration and declining output, the KRG has pressed on with reforms, abandoned the rouble zone and introduced the Kyrgyz Som (KGS), the new currency. Its privatization program has made substantial progress. 1.2 The private enterprise sector is growing rapidly as a result of the privatization program and new entry spurred by other complementary on-going economic and institutional reforms. The Kyrgyz Republic Government and the emerging private sector need support to ensure success of the reform program. This is particularly important since the Kyrgyz Republic is at the forefront of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) in reforming its economy. Policy support for this program of reforms is being provided by the Bank Group under the recently approved Privatization and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (PESAC), which focuses particularly on the acceleration of the privatization program and creating a better policy environment for private sector development. The proposed project has been designed in this context to support an integrated program of financial and technical assistance to enterprises to build up their competitiveness in a market economy. The Credit proceeds would be channelled through a Fund for Enterprise Restructuring and Development (FERD) to be managed by a private Enterprise Fund Manager (FM) being recruited internationally. The FM will work with a counterpart Kyrgyz commercial bank, satisfactory to the Bank, and will also manage the technical assistance support to enterprises. These institutional arrangements have been devised to implement the project on a timely and urgent basis, and thus provide needed resources to private enterprises. These arrangements are required because local banks do not have either the operational capacity or the requisite capital base to support a lending program of the magnitude currently needed to support the investment needs of private sector enterprises. Local banks will be encouraged to assist in co-financing individual projects through provision of working capital or medium term loans in local currency, and may be offered the opportunity to purchase FERD loans if they develop sufficient capacity in the future to administer the loan portfolio.
 - 2 - II. THE INDUSTRIAL AND ENTERPRISE SECTOR A. Background 2.1 Although one of the least industrialized republics of the FSU, the Kyrgyz Republic's industrial sector accounts for a relatively high 30 percent of GDP and 20 percent of employment whereas agriculture accounts for 40 percent of GDP and 40 percent of employment. Most medium and large Kyrgyz enterprises were established as elements of a much larger production system. They are thus either producers of intermediate parts or products for other plants in the FSU or assembled final products from components or inputs procured from other republics. This strategy attached a high value to economies of scale exemplified by very large plant sizes and a high degree of specialization. Installed plant capacities were geared to serve the national or regional markets and rarely reflected local supply or demand considerations. Typical examples of these are the million unit truck radiator plants, the vending machine plant for the entire FSU, kitchen equipment plant for naval vessels and the float glass plant established to supply all of central Asia. B. Progress in Privatization and Enterprise Reform 2.2 The Kyrgyz Republic Government (KRG) began economic reform, stabilization and structural adjustment in 1991, much ahead of other countries of the Former Soviet Union (FSU). The privatization program in particular, which forms an important part of these reforms was accelerated during 1993. By June 1994, approximately 4,800 enterprises, or roughly 40 percent of the State's assets had been privatized. This performance is largely consistent with the initial targets set in the privatization program. It is expected that an additional 35 percent of state assets would be privatized by end 1996. The pace of privatization has been rapid in manufacturing where some 221 enterprises, representing 39 percent of total State enterprise in the medium-large category assets, had been privatized by October, 1993. Some 2,550 small- scale enterprises (SSEs with less than 200 employees) in retail trade and services have been privatized to date, out of an estimated total of 4,300 expected to be privatized. While the program was speedily implemented, it suffered from some major drawbacks. Competitive forms of transfer were dropped after some initial attempts. Shares were transferred in large blocks to employees collectively, rather than individually, in the case of industrial enterprises. Moreover, the privatized enterprises were set up as closed companies which prevented any form of sale of shares to outsiders. Managers had privileged access to large blocks of shares (as high as 25 percent) giving rise to widespread perceptions of unfairness among the populace. Finally, the State Property Fund (SPF, the privatization agency) restricted the activity profile of the privatized enterprises merely precluding flexibility in restructuring. 2.3 These privatization and other related economic policy reform issues, which shed doubt on privatized enterprises behavior, and capacity to move into the market
 economy, are being addressed by the Government in its new Program for 1994-1995, approved by Parliament in December 1993, and agreed with IDA under the Privatization and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (PESAC). The new Program establishes competitive sales methods such as auctions and bidding against cash and vouchers for small-scale enterprises and competitive cash bidding by individuals and groups for up to 70 percent of equity, combined with sale of 25 percent of equity through voucher auctions, for medium and larger enterprises. 2.4 Implementation of the revised privatization program under PESAC is progressing well. As of end October 1994, 90 joint-stock companies were auctioned through 10 sets of cash auctions while 12 new investment funds are actively involved in the mass privatization program. An additional 343 joint-stock companies are expected to be auctioned off by June 1995. Sectoral and macro-economic policy issues impeding the efficient functioning of private enterprises are also being successfully addressed under PESAC including the lifting of controls over prices and profit margins, elimination of compulsory State orders and supply contracts, elimination of export licensing and phased elimination of export taxes, limiting the number and types of enterprises to be considered monopolies and strengthening of the legal and regulatory framework to facilitate and clarify commercial transactions. In particular, a new company law and insolvency law and new regulations on leases and registration of land titles, securities and companies are being drafted. The above measures are progressively creating an appropriate enabling environment to foster private sector activity. Through the PESAC operation, IDA will continue to monitor the effectiveness of the measures and assist the Government with other actions deemed necessary. C. Structure and Performance 2.5 As the key characteristic of the industrial structure was its vertical integration and heavy dependence on trade with other CIS enterprises, the breakdown in inter-republican trade and payments arrangements has hit the industrial sector especially hard. Industrial output was stagnant during the early 1990's. In 1992, real output was estimated to have declined by 23 percent and to have fallen further by around 30 percent in 1993. In 1991, inter republican imports and exports represented 45 and 35 percent of GDP. Foreign trade dependence of the industrial sector was even higher, estimated at over 75 percent of material inputs and outputs. 2.6 Accurate data on the distribution of firms by sub-sector or size is unavailable. However, based on data compiled by the State Property Fund (SPF) in 1991, at the start of the privatization program, the distribution of enterprises by broad activity categories and size is indicated in Tables 2.1 and 2.2. Out of a total of 5,270
 state enterprises' employing 925,000 workers and managers, 4,300 (81.6 percent) were small units (employing less than 200 workers) with about 24 percent of total employment. Twenty very large enterprises (employing more than 5,000 workers) accounted for 16 percent of employment and the remaining 950 were medium and large enterprises with 60 percent of employment. The industrial sector including agro-industry and construction comprised some 700 medium and large firms. Although the number of industrial enterprise is quite large, there are a number of industries where a single or small number of firms dominate the market (e.g. sugar, glass, sparkling wine etc.). Moreover, enterprises in certain industries continue to be organized under holding companies or Concerns. The most important Concerns cover construction (Kurulush); food and beverage processing (Tamak'ash); gold, coal and other mining (Altyn and Kumtor); pharmaceutical (Farmindustria); and forest industries (Lesprom). Although the functions of Concerns have changed in the past few years, their presence and activities in procurement and marketing could inhibit competition in these industrial branches. 2.7 Accurate data on the breakdown of sectoral value added is also unavailable, but some rough numbers presented below provide a qualitative picture of the industrial sector (see project file for details). The food processing and beverage industry has some 100 significant enterprises covering meat packing and dairy operations, tobacco, oils and fats, sugar, candy, alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages and food canning. Most agricultural raw materials are of local origin but packaging materials are imported. However, the sugar industry comprises four large refineries that were designed to process 500,000 tons of raw Cuban sugar for sale throughout Central Asia. The textiles sector comprises 13 multi-plant enterprises processing cotton (28,000 tons/yr.), wool (11,000 tons/yr.) and silk (600 tons/yr.). About 45 percent of production is exported. Most textile plants are not integrated and specialize in individual products. As a result of the Kyrgyz Republic's large sheep and cattle population, the leather and fur garments industry is well developed with 10 leather tanning and footwear making factories and 25 fur garment making plants. The wood and chemicals sub-sector is fairly small and produces household chemicals, paints etc. for local consumption based on imported inputs. 2.8 The two largest industrial sub-sectors are building materials and engineering industries. The building materials industries comprise some 30 enterprises employing over 10,000 workers under the Building Mate,ials Concern. Products include float glass, sawn marble, bricks and cement. Plants are large capital intensive investments supplying products to a wide region. The engineering industries include about 100 medium to large size plants, many producing defense related items and mostly located in the Bishkek region. In addition, there are a large number of mining and metal processing industries of a highly specialized nature including gold (2 tons/yr.), Uranium U308 (100 tons/yr.), antimony (400 tons/yr.), mercury (2,100 tons/yr.) molybdenum (500 tons/yr.) and various rare earths. D. Recent Sectoral Developments 2.9 The breakdown in the trade and payments system as a result of the disintegration of the FSU has had a severe negative impact on Kyrgyz industry, affecting in particular, those which traded a substantial part of their output or input with other republics. Industrial capacity utilization as of the end of 1993 ranged from 20 to 50 percent (based on one shift operations) with consumer goods industries serving local markets operating at the higher limits. Enterprise managers face a complex set of problems in keeping their businesses going. The most serious is the liquidity crisis because of the ubiquitous lack of cash, particularly for financing transactions outside the Republic. Complex barter arrangements involving several parties are undertaken to obtain raw materials and proceeds of sales. Reduced number of days of operation, involuntary salary cuts and redundancies (up to 30 percent in some enterprises) have been implemented by enterprise management to cut costs and conserve scarce cash. Bank credit is extremely scarce and relatively expensive (published interest rates do not reflect loan costs because of large up-front commissions and compensating balances as high as 50 percent of the loan amount). The inability of commercial banks to provide export credit and marketing advice is an additional problem inhibiting export activities of enterprises. Finally, the non-transparent tax system continues to bedevil enterprise management. A serious problem faced by workers is the progressive loss of social and infrastructural services (medical, heating, education) provided by large enterprises. 2.10 The prospects for revival of demand for Kyrgyz products in the CIS is uncertain at best as GDP continues to fall steeply in most of the (FSU) republics. Also the opening up of markets in the CIS has sharply changed market characteristics and introduced competition from non CIS sources for the first time. Even if the trade and payment system is strengthened, Kyrgyz enterprises will need to compete with other suppliers in exporting to CIS markets in the same manner that they will need to do in selling to hard currency markets. To successfully make this transition, enterprises will need to dramatically upgrade product quality to international specifications, reduce operating costs and meet strict delivery schedules. They will also need to build up export marketing capability to support their sales drive in these markets. 2.11 Enterprises can make this transition efficiently if they are operating in an environment which is not hobbled by market failures and policy distortions. Enterprise reform and restructuring is needed not only to respond to relative price adjustments, but also to correct the distortions of the old system whose priorities were established to suit the needs of the FSU. The Kyrgyz Government has taken substantial
 - 6 - steps in the past three years to lay the foundations of a free market economy. The passage of a new constitution guaranteeing private property rights and the aggressive implementation of a wide spread privatization program, even if faulted on certain aspects, are notable achievements. A number of legal and regulatory measures have been enacted to establish the basis for private commercial activity. At the same time, major economic reforms have been implemented in the areas of monetary, fiscal and exchange rate policies and the creation of new institutions. Sectoral issues are addressed under PESAC (para. 2.4). There are a number of enterprise-level issues which need to be resolved quickly if the enterprise sector is to adjust to the new economic realities of the market place. E. Enterprise Level Issues 2.12 Industrial enterprises face a wide variety of difficult problems although the complexity varies by industrial branch. The consumer goods industries selling in the domestic market have relatively fewer problems compared to the capital goods and building materials industries that were designed to export a major part of their output to the other republics. Most enterprises lack access to raw materials, consumable and spares and thus cannot operate production lines efficiently at the present time. However, even domestically oriented Kyrgyz enterprises will face strong competition from imports as external trade is liberalized. Bringing about substantial improvements in productivity at the enterprise level will require a change in management and worker mentality, the incentive system for workers and managers, new investment to modernize obsolete plants and substantial technical assistance to introduce modem management systems and procedures, marketing techniques and distribution networks. Very few enterprises can resolve these problems on their own and will need external assistance to address these problems in a systematic manner. The major issues that need to be tackled for every enterprise are as follows: (a) Training of management in modern managerial practices, particularly in marketing and financial management; (b) Introduction of standardized cost accounting, production planning, inventory control and other management information systems to reduce operational costs and improve efficiency; (c) Improvements in maintenance management to minimize production downtime and improve plant performance; (d) Introduction of performance linked wage and salary systems to improve worker productivity and management performance; (e) Investment in the elimination of bottlenecks and replacement of critical equipment and spares,
 - 7 - (f) Implementation of technical redesign and value engineering programs to enhance product quality and meet international standards, e.g. ISO 9000; and (g) Assistance in the preparation of restructuring plans and export marketing plans to enable enterprises diversify exports to hard currency markets. 2.13 The most cost-effective and low-risk strategy for tackling these problems would be to find foreign firms willing to enter into joint-venture agreements. The prospective international bank to be recruited to manage the Bank financial lending operations, will endeavor to attract joint venture partners from market economies to assist enterprises in their modernization and restructuring efforts. However, as the supply of potential partners is limited, Bank aims to support interested enterprises with technical assistance from qualified international firms. Interventions to assist enterprises are needed as there are serious gaps in the supply of market information and management expertise. Until such time as private firms can find their own solutions, it is essential to arrange for foreign consultants to fill these gaps. The financial situation of most Kyrgyz enterprises would preclude them from hiring qualified consultants - thus the proposed project supports the use of technical assistance needed by these enterprises at least at the initial stages in addressing these problems (para. 5.8) In view of the urgency to address these problems during project preparation, advanced funding from a Japanese Government grant has been provided for diagnostic and pre-feasibility studies of about 30 enterprises, and for establishment of regional information centers. 2.14 A major impediment to the entry of entrepreneurs in new activities is the lack of information on products, markets, and finance. The present situation is characterized by an ad-hoc approach to investment decision-making often leading to adverse results. In particular, small and medium scale entrepreneurs have virtually no access to information about market economies in order to prepare business plans for starting new economic activities. Under advanced funding from the Japanese grant, $250,000 has been allocated to establish regional information centers in the Kyrgyz Republic's seven oblasts to provide local business enterprises with access to information on products, markets and other required data. III. THE KYRGYZ FINANCIAL SECTOR A. Introduction 3.1 The Kyrgyz economy has hitherto been characterized by a dearth of market-based financial institutions, instruments, commercial practices, markets and a regulatory environment that are features of the financial system in a market economy. The com mercial banks lack the infrastructure, skills and institutional capabilities required for efficient financial intermediation and enterprise restructuring. Moreover, the
 commnercial banks continue to face an enterprise sector that continues to experience difficulties. Non-performing loans, averaging 30 to 60 percent of total portfolio in several commercial banks, are increasing as enterprise reform and restructuring progress, hard budget constraints are imposed, and a rising number of enterprises fail to service loans. Management, particularly in the large banks, remains poor, and credit skills are lacking in most banks--thus there is a risk of continued poor lending. Considerable institutional building and possibly restructuring and downsizing of existing commercial banks are required before the banking sector can act as an efficient vehicle to channel resources to private enterprises. Most importantly, financial sector reforms and reforms of enterprises need to be integrated into a coherent strategy. The following is a summary of the structure and performance of the financial system, and a review of the latest sector policy developments and issues. More details on the characteristics and prospects of Kyrgyz banks are provided in the project files and attached tables. B. Institutional Structure 3.2 The Kyrgyz financial sector consists of the Central Bank (NBK), 19 commercial banks (including the former State Savings Bank), an insurance sector and the State pension fund. The commercial banking system dominates the financial system as a source of credit. In February 1992, the State Bank (GOSBANK) was replaced by the NBK, when a two-tier banking system was established with the passage of the Law on Banks and Banking Activities and the Law on the National Bank. The structure and lending operations of the banking system are detailed in Table 3.1. 3.3 Fonner State Banks. Three large former State banks, namely Agroprombank, Kyrgyzstan Bank and Promstroy Bank, which have been corporatized, dominate the commercial banking sector. Promstroy and Agroprom banks are virtually bankrupt since July 1993, while AKB Kyrgyzstan has lately turned into a large loss- maker, and faces difficult times ahead. Until recently the AKB Kyrgyzstan Bank appeared to be the most promising and potentially viable of the above three, and is among the three participating banks selected by EBRD to receive technical assistance under its line of credit. It is estimated that these three banks account for over 80 percent of the commercial loans outstanding and as such are major determinants of the solvency of the banking system. The former State-owned savings bank, the Sberbank, which previously enjoyed a monopoly on the collection of household deposits, has diversified its activities to those of a full commercial bank. The Sberbank continues to be treated, however, as a special case, exempt, for example, from the 20 percent reserve requirement of other commercial banks. The privatization of forner State banks remains questionable as their ownership is still dominated by State owned enterprises as detailed in Table 3.1 and summarized below: Agroprombank finances State agricultural production and food processing enterprises, and consumer cooperatives engaged in food distribution. The bank was converted to a joint stock enterprise in December 1991. Majority ownership
 belongs to agro-processing related State enterprises and consumer cooperatives. The bank has 51 branches and over 1,100 employees. It is the largest bank, in terms of loans, and branch networks; Kvrgvzstan Bank (AKB) finances primarily the agro-business and textiles sectors. It was incorporated as a joint-stock bank in December 1991. Ownership is divided between 45 percent private and 55 percent State commercial and manufacturing enterprises. The bank has 25 branches and over 800 employees. It is the second largest bank, in terms of loans; Promstroy Bank specializes in the energy, mining and construction sectors. Converted to a joint-stock enterprise in December 1991, it has 27 branches and over 750 employees. More than 70 percent of the ownership belongs to State- owned enterprises. In terms of loans portfolio, it is the third largest bank. 3.4 New Private Banks. In addition to the AKB Kyrgyzstan, EBRD has pre- selected two banks among the most promising of the new breed of small and medium size private banks, namely the Kurulush Bank and the Kyrgyz Vneshcom Banks. These smaller banks are under the control of privatized, former SOE borrowing clients. Lately the Kyrgyz Vneshcom bank has run into serious problem loans, stopped lending and is now under special surveillance from NBK's supervision department which has excluded it from all NBK windows, including the credit auction. NBK has directed that Vneshcom (as well as the AKB Kyrgyzstan) be recapitalized by their private shareholders, and put three other small private banks under the same surveillance regime. Among the 10 small and medium banks still operating normally, only Kurulush, Henfen, Orient, and Kramds banks (Table 3.2) offer a relatively comprehensive range of banking services and have paid-up capital in excess of the new minimum establishment level for local banks (KGS5 million-US$500,000 equivalent).2 Only 6 of these smaller banks have one or more branches (Table 3.3). This group of smaller commercial banks, with a stable financial base, enjoy progressive management and show some potential of developing into relatively efficient financial intermediaries, provided, however, that they receive adequate institutional building support, and improve the quality of their portfolio and lending management. In agreement with the IDA, NBK has selected the German- Kyrgyz Industrial Bank Orient (Orient Bank) which will be associated with the international bank being recruited to manage a proposed Fund for Enterprise Restructuring and Development (FERD) slated to intermediate IDA funds (paras. 6.4- 6.9). Details on the Orient Bank's ownership and structure are presented in Annex 1. 3.5 The Insurance Sector. The insurance service market in the Kyrgyz Republic has witnessed significant growth, with more than 50 insurance companies being established since 1991. The State Insurance Company continues to dominate the sector, 2 For joint venture and foreign banks the minimum capital is US$1.0 million.

Many of the new companies are on the verge of bankruptcy, largely as a result of providing insurance coverage on bank loans. (Payments during 1993 on claims under "credit" insurance were 136 percent of the premiums received.) Six of the commercial banks and some State enterprises (such as the railways) established insurance companies dedicated to their specific insurance requirements. In the area of "credit" insurance, there appears to be some confusion between the notion of a guarantee and the notion of insurance. 3.6 Pension Fund. The Pension Fund is only marginally viable, with payments often subject to delays as a result, for example, of individual enterprises delay/inability to meet their required contribution to the scheme. In the short term, issues relating to the Pension Fund are being addressed under the IDA Social Safety Net Credit (Cr. 2643-KG) approved in June 1994. A package of reforms to the existing pension scheme are envisaged in order to maintain its short-term viability and allow staff of the Pension Fund to be re-deployed to administer the social assistance scheme. The medium to long term issues will be addressed under an European Union project, which will concentrate on policy, legislation, revenue collection and institutional strengthening. 3.7 Capital Markets. Technical assistance to develop capital markets is being provided by USAID consultants. A legal and regulatory framework is already in place, although it needs to be fine-tuned and strengthened. The USAID technical assistance program includes four elements: (i) strengthening the State Agency on Securities and improving the Securities Law; (ii) setting up a stock exchange and a voucher exchange and elaborating the rules thereof; (iii) developing the associated institutions such as the clearing system, and training brokers/dealers; and (iv) examining the question of investment funds-the legal framework, operation, and training thereof. No other donor involvement appears warranted at this stage for additional assistance for capital market development. C. Performance of Commercial Banks 3.8 Loan Portfolio. In general, the performance of the financial institutions reflects the difficulties being experienced by the enterprise sector. These difficulties have been compounded by the lending practices of some commercial banks, such as preferential lending to shareholders/owners, which has led to poor allocation of credit, and a subsequent increase in problem loans and narrower intermediation spreads. Their sector-specific loan portfolio, with exposure to State enterprises, accumulation of arrears between enterprises, loss of markets, and decreased sales revenues of borrowers, appear to be the main causes of loan non-performance. The non-performing loans of these banks are expected to be downsized to some extent under the PESAC Credit, by the Enterprise Reform and Resolution Agency (ERRA). Its evolution has been based on a combination of (i) the recent relaxation in Government regulations over the activities of both public and private enterprises, (ii) the progress made in privatization (by June, 1994, approximately 4,800 enterprises or roughly 40% of the State's assets had been privatized) and (iii) an increase in entrepreneurial activities. 2. Thus, even though the transformation from a centrally planned to a market economy is proving difficult in the Kyrgyz Republic (as it is in all of the CIS countries) and most enterprises in both the private and public sector are operating at low capacity utilization levels, (on average 40%), there are certain enterprises which have taken a great deal of initiative and are actually making the necessary adjustments to become competitive. An issue critical to determining their ability to succeed in this transition, however, will be their ability to access capital. And at present, virtually all Kyrgyz enterprises are unable to satisfy their demand for either working capital or medium to long term credit. 3. A number of enterprises which had foreign markets before are working to maximize sales to these markets by adding new or widening existing production lines or improving their production quality. Other enterprises which had previously sold primarily in the domestic market before, are exploring the possibility of exporting to new markets with either new products or an improved version of an existing line. At other enterprises, management is focused on meeting domestic demand - this is the case particularly in food processing and cenain textile enterprises. In all cases, however, there is a demand for hard currency and nearly every enterprise understands the benefits of establishing a means to transform its production into hard currency. 4. Nearly all of the firms visited had one or more investment projects. Many of these, however, were poorly defined or unrealistic in terms of their market potential. doc.repnme: The Kyrgyz Republic - Private Enterprise Support Project
doc.abstracts: The key objective of the Private Enterprise Support Project is to provide an integrated program of technical assistance and loans for working capital and investment for private enterprise to promote their successful adaptation to a market based system. The project is designed to foster the development of the private sector economy through: the development of an effective system of providing technical assistance to enterprises and credit to private enterprises; and strengthening of key project and other selected financial institutions. The project comprises two components: 1) an investment lending component to be channelled through a Fund for Enterprise Restructuring and Development (FERD) established by the government to provide medium term foreign exchange loans to export oriented and selected import-substituting projects of private enterprises; and 2) a technical assistance component which includes funding for management of the FERD, private enterprise support, financial sector studies, project coordination inclusive of consulting services, and audit of project accounts.
